title: Git: Sync Changes repeatedly asks for GitHub credentials for private repositories despite being logged in
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- **VS Code Version:**
```
Version: 1.104.0-insider
Commit: 2c749892adf66679e282a1b27ae526cf995d6f0c
Date: 2025-08-08T05:04:59.345Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 5.15.0-116-generic
```
- **OS Version:** Linux x64 5.15.0-116-generic (Ubuntu)

### Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open a **private** GitHub repository.
2.  Ensure you are successfully logged into your GitHub account via the 'Accounts' menu in the Activity Bar.
3.  Trigger any remote Git operation that requires authentication. For example:
    *   Click the **'Synchronize Changes'** button in the Status Bar (next to the branch name). This action performs a `git fetch`.
    *   Run the `Git: Push` or `Git: Sync` command from the Command Palette.
4.  **Expected behavior:** The Git operation completes successfully using the existing authenticated session.
5.  **Actual behavior:** A prompt appears at the top of the window, asking to provide GitHub credentials. This happens on every attempt to interact with the remote private repository.

### Additional Context

This appears to be a recent regression in the Insider builds.

It is important to note that the repository is **private**. This issue might not be reproducible with public repositories, as `fetch` operations on them often do not require authentication. This strongly suggests the issue lies within the authentication flow for private repos.

The core of the problem seems to be that the built-in Git extension is not using the credentials provided by the **GitHub Authentication** extension, despite the latter reporting a successful login. The output from the **GitHub Authentication** channel confirms that sessions are being found and verified correctly, with no network errors:

```
2025-08-09 14:44:24.240 [info] Reading sessions from keychain...
2025-08-09 14:44:24.240 [info] Got stored sessions!
2025-08-09 14:44:24.240 [info] Got 3 verified sessions.
2025-08-09 14:44:24.944 [info] Getting sessions for read:user,repo,user:email,workflow...
2025-08-09 14:44:24.944 [info] Got 1 sessions for read:user,repo,user:email,workflow...
2025-08-09 14:45:23.890 [info] Getting sessions for read:user,repo,user:email...
2025-08-09 14:45:23.891 [info] Got 1 sessions for read:user,repo,user:email...
```

This suggests the authentication provider is working, but the Git integration is failing to consume the provided token for operations on private repositories.

title: Fix prompt input model to preserve trailing whitespace after window reload
body:
When using `${shellPromptInput}` in terminal tab descriptions, trailing whitespace is lost after reloading the window. For example:

**Before window reload:**
- User types: `ls ` (command with trailing space)
- Terminal tab shows: `ls |` (space visible before cursor)

**After window reload:**
- Terminal tab shows: `ls|` (trailing space lost)

## Root Cause

The issue occurs because `PromptInputModel.deserialize()` was calling `_sync()` which recalculates trailing whitespace from the current terminal buffer state. During window reload, the terminal buffer may not yet reflect the saved state, causing the correctly serialized trailing whitespace to be overwritten with incorrect data.

## Solution

Updated `PromptInputModel.deserialize()` to:
- Fire `_onDidChangeInput` event to notify UI components (like terminal tabs) that state has been restored
- Remove the `_sync()` call that was overwriting the correctly serialized trailing whitespace

The fix preserves the originally saved trailing whitespace while ensuring UI components are notified of the state restoration.

## Testing

Added a comprehensive test that validates:
- Serialization captures trailing whitespace correctly  
- Deserialization fires the change event to ensure UI updates
- State is properly restored with trailing whitespace preserved

Fixes #260746.

title: Invasive

title: Copilot Agent: "N files changed" panel in Copilot Chat occupies large area and obscures chat output when many files change
body:
## Environment

- VS Code version: <e.g. 1.XX.X>
- OS: <Windows 11 / macOS / Linux and build>
- GitHub Copilot extension version: <e.g. GitHub Copilot (Preview) vX.Y.Z>
- Copilot/Agent mode used: <e.g. Copilot Chat (Agent mode) / "Allow task run" flows>
- Workspace type: <single-repo / multi-root workspace>
- Any relevant settings (if changed from defaults):
  - `"copilot.experimental.agent": <true|false>`
  - Other Copilot/Chat related settings: `<list>`

## Reproduction Steps

1. Open VS Code with the GitHub Copilot Chat extension (agent mode) enabled.
2. Start an agent action that modifies multiple files (e.g. allow Copilot to run a build/service task or an automated refactor which changes many files).
3. Observe the Copilot Chat right panel after the agent finishes or asks for confirmation: a list of changed files appears with a preview and diff controls (labelled like `N files changed`).
4. When the number of files is > ~4–5, the file-change list expands and occupies a large portion of the Copilot Chat panel, pushing/covering the actual chat messages and making the conversation hard to read (see attached screenshot).

## Actual Behavior

- The `N files changed` section expands to show many file entries and thumbnails, taking up most of the Copilot Chat panel height.
- This leaves only a small area for the chat content and interrupts readability and flow.
- The panel appears non-collapsed by default and requires manual dismissal/scrolling to see the chat.

## Expected Behavior

- The `N files changed` summary should be compact by default. For example:
  - Show a single compact summary row with file count and a single-expander control (collapsed state), or
  - Limit the max-height of the file list and provide an explicit "Expand / Collapse" control, or
  - Provide a user setting to control the file-list max-height or default collapsed state.
- The chat content should remain the primary focus; file diffs should not obscure the chat unless explicitly expanded by the user.

## Workarounds

- Manually collapse/hide the file-change section (if UI provides a control).
- Resize the Copilot panel or undock the panel to view the full chat (not ideal).

## Suggested Fixes / UX Improvements

- Default the file-change list to **collapsed** with a summary line like `8 files changed — expand to view`.
- Add a compact mode and a persistent user setting, e.g.:
  - `copilot.chat.filePreview.defaultCollapsed: true`
  - `copilot.chat.filePreview.maxHeight: 250` (pixels)
- Make the file-list panel resizable independently from the chat output (drag handle) and remember last state per workspace.
- Provide an option to open the file diffs in the editor or a separate tab instead of inside the chat panel.

## Additional Context

- This is particularly disruptive when the agent performs broad refactors or auto-saves many files as part of a task — the UI steals the conversation context and requires extra clicks to regain it.
- I can reproduce reliably with the following flow: `<brief steps to reproduce in your setup>`.

title: Cannot create new profile from Python Template – Save does not work, must discard, Extensions copy fails (v1.103.0)

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?**: Yes

**VS Code Version:** 1.103.0 (user setup)  
**Commit:** e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f  
**OS Version:** Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 (Windows 10 Home 22H2, OS build 19045.6093)

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open the Profiles UI (Manage > Profiles > New Profile)
2. Set the "From Template" dropdown to "Python"
3. Try to select/deselect configuration checkboxes (especially "Extensions")
4. Click "Create Profile" and select "Trust Publishers" from the dialog box if prompted.
5. Observe: The Save button becomes unresponsive and the profile is not saved when "Extensions" is selected from the Python template. Cannot proceed.

**Expected:**  
Should be able to select/deselect configurations and create a new profile from the Python template, including copying extensions.

**Actual:**  
The profile will not save, and you cannot switch to the unsaved profile when copying extensions from the Python template. This issue persists even in the latest VS Code version. Other templates do not have this issue.

**Workarounds:**  
- Unchecking "Extensions" allows profile creation, but then extensions are not copied.
- Copy the profile "Extensions" manually from [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/configure/profiles#_python-profile-template) for the "Python Profile Template".
- Other templates (e.g., Node.js) work as expected.

**Additional Notes:**  
- There is no "New Profiles UI" setting in this version.
- This is a regression; profile creation used to work.
- The problem seems specifically related to copying extensions from the Python template.
- Previous issues (#224788, #230054, #226563, #226533, #198518) were closed or marked as fixed, but the bug still exists in 1.103.0.

**Please re-investigate, as this is still affecting users in the latest VS Code releases.**

title: open with code context menu missing

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Description:
The “Open with Code” right-click context menu option in Windows Explorer is missing or broken.
I have already reinstalled VS Code multiple times, making sure to check the options for adding “Open with Code” to the file and directory context menus, as well as creating desktop shortcuts, but the option either does not appear or appears but does not work.

In one case, I tried manually adding the context menu by running:

"C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code\bin\code.cmd" --install-shell-context

This did make the option appear in the right-click menu, but when I clicked it, I got a “file not found” error because it was pointing to the wrong path.

The --install-shell-context command also shows this warning:

Warning: 'install-shell-context' is not in the list of known options, but still passed to Electron/Chromium.

This suggests that this option may have been removed in recent builds, which makes it impossible to reinstall the context menu from the command line.


Expected Behavior:
"Open with Code" should appear in the right-click context menu and open the selected folder/file in VS Code.

Actual Behavior:
The option is missing entirely after installation.

If manually added via the --install-shell-context method, the option appears but clicking it shows a "not found" error.

The command also warns that install-shell-context is not a recognized option.

Additional Information:

I have uninstalled and reinstalled VS Code multiple times, making sure to check the relevant context menu options each time.

I tried both the system-wide install (C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code) and user-level install (%LocalAppData%\Programs\Microsoft VS Code).

Possible Cause:
It seems that the context menu registration logic is either:

Not running during installation (even when the boxes are checked), or

Broken in recent builds due to the removal of the --install-shell-context flag.

**Title:** "Open with Code" Missing from Windows Context Menu (All Fixes Tried)

**Description:**

The "Open with Code" option is missing from the right-click context menu in Windows Explorer. This option typically appears after installing Visual Studio Code, enabling quick opening of folders or files. Despite trying all known fixes, the option does not appear, impacting workflow efficiency.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Right-click any folder or file in Windows Explorer.
2. Observe the absence of the "Open with Code" option.

**Expected Behavior:**

"Open with Code" should be present in the context menu for quick VS Code launching.

**Environment:**

* Windows version: Windows 10 (Build 26100, x64)
* Visual Studio Code version: 1.103.0 (system setup)
* Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f
* Electron: 37.2.3
* Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
* Node.js: 22.17.0

**Troubleshooting Already Attempted:**

* Verified and reinstalled VS Code with "Add to PATH" and "Add 'Open with Code' actions" options enabled.
* Used `code --install-context-menu` (or equivalent) commands to register context menu entries.
* Checked and repaired registry entries related to VS Code shell integration.
* Restarted Windows Explorer and the system multiple times.
* Verified user permissions and group policies that might block context menu modifications.
* Attempted manual registry edits to restore context menu entries.
* Disabled antivirus/firewall temporarily to rule out interference.

**Request:**

Please investigate this issue further or provide alternative solutions to restore the missing "Open with Code" context menu entry.

title: Create a specification functionality similar to the future IDE that will be released at the end of this month, which is Kiro.

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I consider their approach to this and software specifications to be extremely polished and useful for software development. However, they are extremely lacking in the subscription price they are offering to users. They are charging exorbitant prices for this. If the VS Code team develops a similar feature that has the same effect but consumes fewer credits or is even unlimited, it will probably attract many future Kiro users to use VS Code. The main thing that makes Kiro successful is the way they are handling specification concepts with the agent within the IDE. Here is a link to their documentation where they talk a little more about this and how it works so you can understand what I'm saying:

https://kiro.dev/docs/specs/concepts/

Remember: even if Copilot already has these types of .md files, the idea behind Kiro's specs is that Kiro itself generates these specifications and requirements based on the description the user provided. description it creates everything automatically, with the user being able to ask it to change or the user himself can change something in the files!

Feature 1: #261159
Feature 2: #261160 
Feature 3: #261162 
Feature 4: #261163 
Feature 5: #261164

title: support both vscode and github copilot chat about AGENT.md file and pattern

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Several IDEs and CLIs competing with VScode natively support the agent.md standard, a universal agent specification standard. Even though VScode has its own approach, it should also have this natively. But you might be thinking:

"But if we already have something similar, why would we do this?"

Well, there are several competing IDEs emerging that are implementing software specifications by default within their agent IDEs, and VScode, being the foundation for all of them, should do the same by supporting agent.md.

link of project: https://ampcode.com/AGENT.md

title: Support previewing and merging work tree changes into the current window

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

body: Given a git repo opened in VS Code on a work tree (e.g. the main work tree) with working changes in other work trees, we should make it simple to both view the diff between the 2 work trees and apply those changes directly to the current window much like a stash apply. We should also make it simple to cleanup the work trees after merging.

title: Inherit workspace trust from main work tree
body: When creating a work tree from a repo, given the way VS Code workspace trust works with folders, you have to trust work tree folder when you open that window. It doesn't make a lot of sense given its the same repo and we don't reprompt for trust on branch changes. For this reason, it would be nice to inherit the trust level of the main worktree folder.

title: Make it easier to tell that the current window is a work tree

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: With the new worktree support, the window title for a worktree is often some randomly generated branch name making it harder to distinguish which repo a window/worktree belongs to. It's also not immediately obvious in the SCM view which worktree is active in the window.

title: Disappearing terminal confirmation editors

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body: - get a terminal tool confirmation - click into it - It disappears This is weird- what happened is that the editor's model was disposed, and the editor was removed from the DOM. That happened when the wordHighlighter contrib disposed its reference and there were no remaining refs. I don't know what changed, and I can't repro reliably. I'm a little unsure about the proper flow, I think we are using `createModel` wrong somehow. https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/7ca850c73f7fa37e1fc80090f14268b0b6b504bb/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatContentParts/toolInvocationParts/chatTerminalToolSubPart.ts#L118-L123 In some places like https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/7ca850c73f7fa37e1fc80090f14268b0b6b504bb/src/vs/workbench/contrib/bulkEdit/browser/preview/bulkEditPreview.ts#L443-L448 I see them call `createModelReference` after `createModel`, maybe we are supposed to do that. @Tyriar you've touched this code recently, any idea? I haven't tried to bisect yet.

title: Address user issues collected from socials

labels.name: plan-item
labels.description: VS Code - planned item for upcoming

body:
We have collected a good amount of user feedback in our socials and channels and need to align these with work items existing or new. This is a meta issue tracking work to both read through our collected feedback in channels to prioritize them and highlight our action items.

Items will be added to this list as we review the feedback:
- [x] Message Editing: Allow editing of chat messages after sending @justschen 
- [x] Agent: "Restore to Checkpoint"/Robust Undo: Implement reliable undo/rollback for agent changes, including reverting file additions/deletions @justschen 
- [ ] Support for Thinking Tokens [vscode#257104](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/257104) @justschen 
- [x] Make the changed files UX more lightweight [vscode#260175](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260175) @justschen 
- [ ] Export Chat History [vscode#256366](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256366) @eli-w-king @hawkticehurst 
- [x] Show History in Empty state [vscode#251187](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/251187) @eli-w-king 
- [ ] Smooth Undo Pop-ups: Make undo actions unobtrusive and avoid jarring pop-ups. @hawkticehurst

Copilot and code completion is great because I can multitask while it works. However, I have to keep checking to see when it’s finished and needs my attention. 

I suggest that there be a setting for Copilot so that it can make an HTTP request to an arbitrary endpoint when Copilot has finished responding to a prompt, finished generating code, needs my approval for an agent to act, or otherwise is ready for my attention. We can direct it to a push notification service, a local server that chimes a sound, etc.

title: Add command contribution support for chat session view items
body:
This PR enables extensions to contribute commands to specific chat session view items in the Chat Sessions view. Extensions like the GitHub Pull Request extension can now register context-aware commands that appear as action bar items for individual session items.

## Changes Made

### 1. New Context Keys
Added three new context keys in `chatContextKeys.ts` to provide session-specific context:
- `chatSessionId`: The unique ID of the session item
- `chatSessionLabel`: The display label of the session item  
- `chatSessionType`: The type of session (e.g., 'local', 'github', etc.)

### 2. Enhanced SessionsRenderer
Modified the `SessionsRenderer` in `chatSessions.ts` to support menu contributions:
- Added menu service and context key service dependencies
- Enhanced template data with `elementDisposable` for proper cleanup
- Created context overlay for each session item using the new context keys
- Integrated action bar support with `MenuId.ChatSessionsMenu`
- Added proper disposal methods to prevent memory leaks

## How Extensions Use This

Extensions can now contribute to the existing `ChatSessionsMenu` MenuId with context-aware commands:

```json
{
  "contributes": {
    "menus": {
      "ChatSessionsMenu": [
        {
          "command": "github.createPullRequestFromSession",
          "when": "chatSessionType == 'github'",
          "group": "github",
          "order": 1
        }
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

Commands receive the full session object as an argument:

```typescript
vscode.commands.registerCommand('github.createPullRequestFromSession', (session) => {
  // Access session.id, session.label, session.provider.chatSessionType
  console.log(`Creating PR for session: ${session.label}`);
});
```

## Use Cases

This enables the GitHub Pull Request extension and other extensions to provide rich, session-specific functionality such as:
- Creating pull requests from chat session content
- Viewing associated PRs/issues
- Adding comments to linked items
- Quick management actions

The implementation follows VS Code's standard menu contribution patterns and provides a clean, extensible foundation for session-specific command contributions.

title: Terminal suggest: Support fig additionalSuggestions with proper insertValue handling
body:
This PR implements support for fig's `additionalSuggestions` feature in the VS Code terminal suggestion system. The `additionalSuggestions` field allows completion specs to provide shortcut suggestions alongside regular subcommands.

## What this enables

With this change, when typing `git ` in the terminal, users will now see additional completion suggestions like:

```
commit -m ''     Git commit shortcut
quick-commit
```

The additional suggestions provide quick access to common command patterns with proper text replacement.

## Implementation details

- **Added `addAdditionalSuggestions` function** that processes both string and object suggestions from the `additionalSuggestions` array in fig specs
- **Integrated with existing suggestion flow** by processing additional suggestions when `SuggestionFlag.Subcommands` is set
- **Proper insertValue handling** with `{cursor}` placeholder replacement for command shortcuts
- **Visual differentiation** using `TerminalCompletionItemKind.Alias` for suggestions that specify an icon property

The implementation handles both simple string suggestions and full suggestion objects with properties like `name`, `description`, `insertValue`, and `icon`. When an `insertValue` is provided, it replaces the `{cursor}` placeholder with an empty string since VS Code terminal completions don't support cursor positioning.

## Example from git.ts spec

```javascript
additionalSuggestions: [
  {
    name: "commit -m 'msg'",
    description: "Git commit shortcut",
    insertValue: "commit -m '{cursor}'",
    icon: "fig://template?color=2ecc71&badge=🔥",
  },
]
```

This creates a completion that shows `"commit -m ''"` as the replacement text, allowing users to quickly insert the command template.

## Testing

Updated test coverage to verify the processing logic handles both object and string additional suggestions with proper insertValue replacement.

Fixes #239627.

title: Add missing git cherry-pick flags to terminal suggest completion
body:
The terminal suggest feature was missing some git cherry-pick flags, causing "No suggestions" to appear when users typed `git cherry-pick -` as shown in the issue screenshot.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8a67a59b-3600-4e3a-a652-323c6e22e38b)

This PR adds the missing flags to ensure comprehensive cherry-pick completion:

**Added flags:**
- `-r` - Legacy flag for disabling -x (now a no-op but still supported for compatibility)
- `--empty=(drop|keep|stop)` - Modern flag for handling commits that become redundant after cherry-picking:
  - `drop` - The commit will be dropped
  - `keep` - The commit will be kept (implies --allow-empty)
  - `stop` - Stop when the commit is applied for examination (default behavior)

**Additional improvements:**
- Updated `--keep-redundant-commits` description to note it's deprecated in favor of `--empty=keep`
- Added comprehensive test coverage for cherry-pick flags

The cherry-pick subcommand now includes all 28 available git cherry-pick flags, ensuring users get proper suggestions when typing `git cherry-pick -` in the terminal.

Fixes #260160.

title: Automatic MCP Resources inclusion to the context
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
### Background

Model context protocol states:

> Resources are application-driven, giving hosts flexibility in how they retrieve, process, and present available context. Common interaction patterns include tree or list views for browsing resources in familiar folder-like structures, search and filter interfaces for finding specific resources, **_automatic context inclusion based on heuristics or AI selection_**, and manual selection interfaces.

[Source](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/learn/server-concepts#user-interaction-model-2)

Huge thanks to the team for adding nice API for the automatic inclusion of the context from the workspace 🦖 
I find it exciting to have a possibility to automatically load Resources from MCP server to the context too.
Currently, the only way to include MCP Resources to the context is to manually add them **one-by-one**, which is time consuming and distractive.

### Suggestion

I suggest to add the possibility to make Copilot automatically add MCP Resources based on the user configuration or let AI decide what resources required, just like it's done with tools.

### Workaround

I found an acceptable workaround which makes Copilot automatically consider resources without the need to add them manually. You can create an MCP Tool which return content you want to expose to AI. MCP tools are invoked automatically, based on the user intention, so you don't have to.

title: Add write-only mode option for todo tool
body:
The todo tool now supports a write-only mode to prevent unnecessary read operations during new chat turns, since tool invocations remain in context for the agent.

## Changes

**New Configuration Setting:**
- Added `chat.todoListTool.writeOnly` boolean setting (default: false)
- Marked as experimental to match the existing todo tool setting

**Dynamic Schema Generation:**
- Created `createManageTodoListToolData(writeOnly)` function for conditional schema building
- In write-only mode: removes the `operation` parameter entirely, only requires `todoList`
- In normal mode: preserves existing behavior with both 'read' and 'write' operations

**Tool Implementation:**
- Updated `ManageTodoListTool` constructor to accept `writeOnly` parameter
- Modified `invoke()` method to always perform write operations in write-only mode
- Adapted `prepareToolInvocation()` to handle optional operation parameter
- Tool registration now reads configuration to instantiate appropriate version

## Example Usage

**Normal mode** (existing behavior):
```json
{
  "operation": "write",
  "todoList": [{"id": 1, "title": "Fix bug", "description": "...", "status": "not-started"}]
}
```

**Write-only mode** (new):
```json
{
  "todoList": [{"id": 1, "title": "Fix bug", "description": "...", "status": "not-started"}]
}
```

The write-only mode eliminates redundant context checking while maintaining full backward compatibility when the setting is disabled.

Fixes #260687.

See that a few times, agent checks todo lists during a new turn even though. Todo lists can work without reads, as the tool invocation remains in context for the agent.

Right now the tool as read and write operation. With the write-only setting on, the tool would not have an operation parameter; and would only handle write.

There are open questions how clear works, or pinning todos for a workspace; but they could be auto-included in the initial user prompt if needed. For a first cut, this write-only todolist setting can ignore that.

title: Toggle for changed files list
body: ### Philosophy I believe that chat and prompt input are the most important parts. User interacts with them 90% of the time. It's extremely important to keep this interface clean during conversation. ### Problem There is a list of changed files which takes a big portion of the screen real estate, making it less comfortable to read and navigate inside conversation. Copilot applies edits -> User keeps them and proceeds the conversation -> chat window is permanently reduced in size. ### Solution Add toggle button to hide changed files list. Expand list only when new file changes are applied (and by user request of course).

title: Feature Request: ability to automatically include a standard set of directives with each query

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently, when I provide a specific set of directives around how I want Copilot to handle my queries, those directives remain in the context window for some period of time, but may eventually roll off (depending on how long that chat continues).

As a workaround, I can create an external file containing those directives and then periodically remind Copilot to reference it. This re-inserts/bumps them up in the context window. However, I must remember to periodically tell Copilot to reference it, and I don't have visibility to how often it is necessary.

I would find it very useful to be able to identify to the VSCode extension where my directives/prompting file is, and to include (prepend or postpend) it to every request I submit. That would ensure the directives are always in context and followed. I realize that adds some overhead (effectively shrinks the usable context window by duplicating the directives), but it is a tradeoff I am VERY willing to make.
